channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-10554] Please delete old releases from mirroring system
item.description:
To reduce the load on the ASF mirrors, projects are required to delete old releases [1]

Please can you remove all non-current releases?
Thanks!

[1] http://www.apache.org/dev/release.html#when-to-archive
item.summary: Please delete old releases from mirroring system

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Interestingly we got requests from other projects to keep more versions around.

We currently have three active release branches: 0.94, 0.96, and 0.98. All of them are actively developed and actively used.
Since this is a database we have support the older branches going forward with new releases. Having those in "archive" is not appropriate.

I went ahead and deleted the 0.94.14, and 0.94.15 releases, so only 0.94.16 is left.
stack, I assume it's OK to also remove 0.96.0, and 0.96.1? Your call. When we do this we'd have 0.94.16, 0.96.1.1, and 0.98.0 as current releases.
I removed 0.96.0 and 0.96.1. Resolving as addressed. Sorry about that Sebb We'll keep a better eye out in future.

Thanks for the very prompt resolution!

BTW, a good time to check if there are any further releases that can be deleted is when the Announce mail for a new release is sent.
By that time, the mirrors should have caught up (and the download page will have been updated) so it should be safe to delete any superseded release.

Please tidy up the release area. Again.

It looks to me like the following can be deleted:

hbase-0.94.23/
hbase-0.94.24/
hbase-0.96.2/
hbase-0.98.7/
hbase-0.99.0/
hbase-0.99.1/

The directory "to_remove" does not look as though it belongs there.
Remember that this directory is mirrored.

We have four active release branches: 0.94, 0.96, 0.98, 0.99 (1.0 preview). For each active branch, we have the latest release and the one previous, in case users need to roll back. I think this is completely reasonable.

Where did 0.94.25 go?! Looks like it vanished from the mirrors?!
I checked my ssh logs, I definitely copied 0.94.25 to the mirror and deleted 0.94.23. That is very disconcerting.
I also found that /www/www.apache.org/dist/hbase is now owned by user and group svnwc with perms drwxrwsr-x so I cannot re-add 0.94.25 myself.
NM. We changed the process (thanks Andrew Purtell). I'll re-add 0.94.25 via svn.

The ASF release process now uses svnpubsub.

Anything that is stored under

https://dist.apache.org/repos/dist/release/hbase/

will be synched to the ASF mirror masters and thence to the external mirrors

Note: There is also a corresponding staging repo area at

https://dist.apache.org/repos/dist/dev/hbase/

which can be used for release candidates.

If the RC vote passes, just rename the files to the release area.
Saves having to move the files around as much, and provides traceability back to the VOTE e-mail.

I meant to add: to tidy up the release area, the directories need to be removed from

https://dist.apache.org/repos/dist/release/hbase/

Only current, maintained releases should be present there.

So AFAICT, 0.94.25 should NOT be present, as it has been superseded by 0.98.x

Older releases are always available from the archives.

So AFAICT, 0.94.25 should NOT be present, as it has been superseded by 0.98.x

This is incorrect, as I have explained above.

We have four active release branches: 0.94, 0.96, 0.98, 0.99 (1.0 preview)

We have active users of 0.94, so no later release "supersedes" it in the manner you suggest. We actively support our 0.94 line and have a RM for it making monthly-ish releases. These are all current releases.

However, it is true we are keeping the latest release and also one version back in dist/. I suppose you can make the argument that we don't need to keep that one version back in dist/, we could point users at the archives. I don't have a personal opinion one way or the other on that, as RM for 0.98 I'm conforming to the evident consensus practice.

Yeah, as Andy says, since HBase is a database we have to continue to make bugfix releases to older releases.
It will become clearer once we switch to semantic versioning, when we'll have (say) 1.0.1, 1.1.3, 1.2.3, and 2.0.1 out at the same time.

I tried to remove 0.94.23 and add 0.94.25, as described, but I always get:

svn: E175002: PUT request on '/repos/dist/!svn/txr/7383-6ei/release/hbase/hbase-0.94.25/hbase-0.94.25.tar.gz' failed: 408 Request Timeout

or

Transmitting file data .svn: E185004: Commit failed (details follow):

svn: E185004: Unexpected end of svndiff input

Is that an issue due to the svn outage?
Sorry for being difficult.
I'm happy to put only the latest point release out on the mirror and the rest in archive.

The page

https://dist.apache.org/repos/dist/release/hbase/HEADER.html

says:

The 0.98.x series is the current stable release, it supercedes 0.94.x and 0.96.x.

My reading of this is that users of 0.94.x should upgrade to 0.98.x, i.e. that 0.94.x is no longer in active development.

If that is an incorrect reading, please clarify the README.

In any case, there should be at most one release of 0.94 and 0.98.
Also 0.96 should not be present at all as it is EOL

My reading of this is that users of 0.94.x should upgrade to 0.98.x, i.e. that 0.94.x is no longer in active development.

Agreed, the README should be better worded. "Active development" != "unsupported and must upgrade". A check of our JIRA will demonstrate that we make approximately monthly releases of 0.94 containing bug fixes.

Also 0.96 should not be present at all as it is EOL

That's fair. stack what do you think?

I removed 0.96. While in there, removed all but the latest on each major branch (0.94, 0.98, and 0.99). Did edit of HEADER to say 0.94 still seeing bug fix releases every month or so for those not yet able to upgrade. Also pointed at apache archive if folks are looking for old versions.

Thanks, that looks much better.

BTW, just noticed a minor trademarks issue in the README - the first instance of HBase should really be Apache HBase
